title: How to Make Traditional Navajo Frybread

steps.headline: Start by mixing in the flour with the baking powder and salt.
Put in about 1/4 teaspoon of salt, and about two tablespoons of baking powder.
Stir the dry ingredients together thoroughly.
Add about 1 tablespoon of lard to the flour.
Blend the lard in with your hand, squeezing away the small bumps as much as possible.
steps.description: Distribute it as best as you can.

steps.headline: You should have enough hot water to make the dough soft and malleable.
steps.description: The water temperature should be bearable to the skin. You may have someone pour the water in for you as you knead the wet flour into dough. While the water is being poured into the flour, use your dominant hand to gently squeeze the mixture, letting it ooze between your fingers. Let the dough mix itself. Do not try to knead it yet.

steps.headline: Add enough water until all the flour is absorbed.
steps.description: It should be sticky, but not watery. Continue to gently squeeze it. There should be no pockets of dry flour. All of it should be absorbed.

steps.headline: When the flour has finally been absorbed enough by the flour, patiently knead the newly-formed dough with the palm and fist of your dominant hand.
steps.description: Fold it inwards from the edges. If the dough is too dry, add drops of warm water when necessary. If the dough is too watery, add flour, rotating the bowl as you knead.

steps.headline: When you are finished, the dough should be pliable, but not gelatinous.
steps.description: If the dough is gelatinous, it has been over-mixed. There should be no bumps in the dough, which indicate pockets of flour. Place the dough in the bowl and cover it with a clean dish towel. Let rest for about 30 minutes.

steps.headline: Melt generous spoonfuls of lard in the pan, enough to allow the frybread to float easily.
steps.description: The frybread dough absorbs lard. If you are making a large batch, you may need to melt more lard as you go.

steps.headline: Let the melted lard heat over a medium heat.
steps.description: If the oil smokes, then turn the heat down, for it has become too hot. Overheated lard could burn the frybread dough.

steps.headline: Squeeze off a palm-sized ball of dough.
steps.description: Gently flatten it out with your fingers, rotating it in a circle, starting with the edges. Pat the dough until it is flat and almost translucent. You may use a rolling pin.

steps.headline: Roll it out into a circle not exceeding the pan size, making sure the thickness is even.
steps.description: The thinner the frybread, the crunchier it will be.

steps.headline: When you have rolled it out enough, carefully place the flattened piece of dough into the pan with a utensil or your hands.
steps.description: The oil may bubble vigorously, but if there are too many bubbles, the oil is too hot. If the oil does not bubble enough, the oil is not hot enough. Caution: Dropping or tossing the dough will splash hot oil that could cause burn injuries.

steps.headline: Poke a hole in the center of the frybread dough immediately after you place the dough in the hot lard.
steps.description: Tend the floating piece of dough using tongs or a long-handled fork. Gently press the center down with a utensil so that hot lard runs through the hole and runs over the top side of the dough. After approximately 20 seconds, use the utensil to carefully turn it over. Fry the bread until it reaches a golden brown color on each side. Overcooked dough is dark brown or black.

steps.headline: Continue until you've used all the dough.
steps.description: Popular toppings include salt, honey, powdered sugar, etc. It's great for any meal.
